citations.narrative:
According to correspondence from a state public health veterinarian, a woman who visited the facility on October 20,
2025, was bitten by a zebra during the drive through encounter. The woman didn’t notify the facility of the incident when it
occurred but sought medical attention after leaving. When the incident was finally reported to the facility, it was relayed
that the woman was feeding the long horns when the zebra approached and bit and broke her thumb. The drive through is
monitored using cameras with two-way radios and attendants are physically present along the route during high traffic
times. No facility staff members were in the immediate area at the time of the incident, and it occurred just outside of the
camera footage in that area. Animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public,
with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of
animals and the public.
Correct from this date (December 9, 2025) forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
